comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The cottage is in the NIAH, dated c. 1870.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Scully Monument was built in 1867, and the top destroyed by lightning in 1976, leaving just a pillar:

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: According to local mythology, the Rock of Cashel originated in the Devil's Bit, a mountain 20 miles (30 km) north of Cashel when St. Patrick banished Satan from a cave, resulting in the Rock's landing in Cashel.[1] Cashel is reputed to be the site of the conversion of the King of Munster by St. Patrick in the 5th century

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Checked on the Super Duper Hi Res image, and it is a dog!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That must have been some thunderstorm!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Danny the story we were always told about the rock was that Fionn McCumhall was challenged to a race across Ireland by Satan and as he was outpaced by Fionn and saw he was going to lose he bit the chunk out of the Devils Bit and spat it out to land just outside Cashel.  The local mythology would also suggest that the rock formation has more in common with the Bit than the Cashel area which is mostly old red sandstone.  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Carol, it was some storm alright and I remember it well, I have a photo somewhere taken at the Scully monument in 1968 when it was intact.  I understood that it was the high wind that night that caused the cross to break.  If it had fallen in the other direction it might have been repaired but it fell outside the walls, down a steep slope and was smashed to smithereens!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 2 dogs in two days - you must really want that Book.....

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Sean - had a Teacher in second class who was raised in the shadow of the Devils Bit - we were told lots and lots of stories about it and the general area - D

Now Carol is going to post a Photo of the Devils Bit - is she not!!!!!!!

PS - it was a CBS school ( I only have very good memories)  - Satan did figure a lot in the stories!!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Another interesting fact is that one of the last Archbishop of the Rock of Cashel was Arthur Price. He’s also famous for being Arthur Guinness’s godfather and also because in his will he gave Arthur Guinness 100 Pounds. With the help of this money Arthur Guinness started to bild his beer empire.

Carol we need a Guinness Photo and one of the old £100 note...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  As an aside - why do you not post the Super Duper hi res image?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] If it's been done with a flatbed scanner at 1200dpi in 24 bit colour, it'd be 9000 x 6000 and 150Mb. That's pretty inconvenient to stick on the internet - it's several times bigger than a typical telemedicine chest x-ray.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] So what the problem8-)
Some (ill informed) people would say that they have nothing else to do in Library Towers all day.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The more you look at this shot the more you appreciate the quality and detail.  This is probably one of the best shots I've ever seen of a truly iconic landmark and national treasure.  Well done Carol, this is a cracker!

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
I'm not even Irish, live on the other side of the world and look forward to your wonderful pictures of Ireland.  You always seem to pick the pictures with character and interest, as is shown by the pretty fantastic response that you always get.
There are a lot of libraries in the world that could take a leaf out of your book, and be the better for it.
So, NLI, thank you for your efforts, they are very much appreciated.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
Another classic Carol, as always, this, (like many others), causes great debate!
Nice to see such comments from the kindness of strangers, Frigate RN.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] ditto (except I am half-Irish) Wikipedia on Rock of Cashel is interesting about the various buildings (see notes). The photographer Robert French seems to have been up high on something (no pun intended) for this photo. Can anyone work out what? On a line with the Round Tower, the NE corner of the cathedral, and Rock Cottage. Near the tower for the Fire Station? GoogleMapsSatelliteView

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] From the church, by the look of it: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,607632,640931,7,9

comment.author: 8233898@N07
comment._content: Wonderful picture

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Do you think so?  According to streetview that church (now "Chez-Hans, est 1968") hasn't got a tall tower.   I thought it might have been from the tower of St Benedicts Abbey (slightly south),  but it is at the wrong angle.  Hmmm ...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There's a big wall behind the church in front of a load of trees. I think its from up on that, looking not quite across the triangle. The cottage/shed in the foreground is the one on the near side of the triangle. If it's not there, I think it must be 30 yards further up moor lane: maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Cashel,+Ireland&hl=en&l...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There is a square tower on the corner of ChezHans, btw, though it has a roof on it now. It might not have had a roof previously - it doesn't look in keeping with the rest of the building.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The NIAH says Chez Hans is from 1880 (then a Methodist Church), but doesn't mention if the tower was altered.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Chez Hans website (the menu looks yummy) has a different history, but no information about the tower either - www.chezhans.net/history.html The cottage in the foreground left with the washing out and boundary walls seems to be the building marked between the two Os in "M O O R" on the 25" map, which implies the photographer was almost where the Fire Station tower is (ie south of the church / Chez Hans). Perhaps up one of those trees marked or something taller to see over them?
